text: Hello people, how does Plotly differ from Plot really? thank you

elements.text: Hello people, how does Plotly differ from Plot really? thank you

text:
Plotly is for interactive plotting (e.g. highlighting your mouse over points, dropdowns, etc...)
Plots are just static plots

elements.text:
Plotly is for interactive plotting (e.g. highlighting your mouse over points, dropdowns, etc...)
Plots are just static plots

text: That's not quite true. You can get interactive plots with Plots.

elements.text: That's not quite true. You can get interactive plots with Plots.

attachments.title: Plotly: The front end for ML and data science models
attachments.text: Plotly creates & stewards the leading data viz & UI tools for ML, data science, engineering, and the sciences. Language support for Python, R, Julia, and JavaScript.
attachments.fallback: Plotly: The front end for ML and data science models

text:
Plots.jl is a API front end over:
GR (default), Plotly, PyPlot, PGFPlotX, UnicodePlots, and InspectDR.
You can change the backend e.g. by runnign `plotly()` after loading it, and it will display plots in that backend (and so for plotly it will have stuff like dragging and zooming).
You can change between backends depending on your needs and the API remains the same (though some support different features so you may get warnings)

Further Plots.jl supports recipes, which are aways to declare how particular julia object are displayed.
For example, Intervals.jl displays as marked-segments (shown is half open intervals)

using Plotly.jl (or PlotlyJS.jl) directly probably exposes more Plotly specific features than using it via Plots.jl.

You can change between backends depending on your needs and the API remains the same (though some support different features so you may get warnings)

Further Plots.jl supports recipes, which are aways to declare how particular julia object are displayed.
For example, Intervals.jl displays as marked-segments (shown is half open intervals)

using Plotly.jl (or PlotlyJS.jl) directly probably exposes more Plotly specific features than using it via Plots.jl.

text:
Thank you all.
For creating a standalone .exe program compiled out of Julia, what would be the best choice for the graphical user interface?
